description: From Latin dubius; like doubt, from Latin duo (cognate to English two), implying “two alternatives” (yes or no, true or false, etc.).

adjectives.description: dubious (comparative more dubious, superlative most dubious)

entries.meaning: (of a statement, matter, or thing) Arousing doubt; questionable; open to suspicion.
examples: After he made some dubious claims about the company, fewer people trusted him.
They were renowned as people of dubious morals.

entries.meaning: (of a person) In disbelief; wavering, uncertain, or hesitating in opinion; inclined to doubt; undecided.
examples: She was dubious about my plan at first, but later I managed to persuade her to cooperate.

entries.meaning: (chess, chiefly of an opening move) Generally considered imprecise or wrong, but not totally unplayable.
